sen.j: 栄爵（えいしゃく）とは、栄誉ある地位或いは爵位のこと。
sen.e: An eishaku indicates an honorable position or rank.
An eishaku indicates an honorable position or rank.

sen.j: あるいは古代・中世の日本における従五位の別称でもある。
sen.e: Or, in ancient times and the medieval period in Japan, it was used as another expression of Jugoi (Junior Fifth Rank).
Or, in ancient times and the medieval period in Japan, it was used as another expression of Jugoi (Junior Fifth Rank).
It was also another name for jugoi (Junior Fifth Rank) during ancient and medieval Japan.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: また、寺社や宮司に与えられた特権を指す用語のひとつとしても用いられる。
sen.e: It is also used as one of the terms indicating a privilege given to a temple, shrine or Guji (chief of those who serve a shrine, control festivals and general affairs).
It wa also used as a term to indicate a privilege given to a temple, shrine or Guji (chief of those who serve a shrine, control festivals and general affairs).
Furthermore, it was also used as a term to express a special privilege given to temples, shrines or guji (chief priests).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 後に位の高い爵位の異称としても用いられた。
sen.e: Later, it was also used as another expression for indicating high ranks.
Later, it was also used to indicate other high ranks.
Later, it was also used to indicate other high ranks.

sen.j: 寺院及び宮司の特権としての栄爵
sen.e: Eishaku as a privilege of a temple, shrine or Guji
Eishaku as a privilege of a temple, shrine or Guji
Eishaku: Special privileges of temples, shrines or guji (chief priests)
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 毎年、寺院ないし宮司に1人分の叙爵権を付与し、寺院及び宮司は叙爵希望者より叙料を納めさせることで、従五位下に叙爵させることができるとされた。
sen.e: There was the following system: Each of a temple, a shrine and a Guji was provided with the right to grant a rank for a person every year, and could grant the rank of Jugoinoge (junior fifth rank), to a person who desired the rank and paid joryo (a fee to attain the rank).

There was the following system: Each temple, shrine and Guji was provided with the right to grant a person rank every year, and could grant the rank of Jugoinoge (junior fifth rank), to a person who desired the rank and paid joryo (a fee to attain the rank).
Each year a temple, shrine or guji could grant the rank of Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade) to one person who desired the rank and who had paid a joryo (a fee to obtain the rank).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 当該制度は平安時代初期にはじまったとされる。
sen.e: It is said that this system started in the early Heian period.
It is said that this system started in the early Heian period.
This system began in the early Heian period.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。

sen.j: 院や三宮に対して叙料を納めさせる代わりに叙爵する年爵と同じく売位によるものであった。
sen.e: It was a system for selling ranks, the same as nenshaku in which a rank was granted of paying joryo to a retired emperor, empress or Sannomiya (third prince).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It was a system for selling ranks, the same as nenshaku in which a rank was granted of paying joryo to a retired emperor, empress or Sannomiya (third prince).
It was a system for selling ranks, the same as nenshaku in which a rank was granted of paying joryo to a retired emperor, empress or Sannomiya (third prince).

sen.j: しかし、平安時代末期から鎌倉時代にかけて栄爵による昇叙(加階)が盛んとなった。
sen.e: However, in the era from around the end of the Heian period to the Kamakura period, gaining an advance in the rank through obtaining eishaku was popular.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, in the era from around the end of the Heian period to the Kamakura period, gaining an advance in the rank through obtaining eishaku was popular.
Advancement through eishaku was quite common from the end of the Heian Period to the Kamakura period.
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。Period小文字にしました。

sen.j: 叙爵申請者が栄爵に際して納める費用を栄爵料、叙爵料といった。
sen.e: The amount of charge that an applicant for an eishaku had to pay for gaining an eishaku was called eishaku-ryo or joshaku-ryo.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The amount an applicant had to pay for eishaku was called eishaku-ryo or joshaku-ryo.
The amount an applicant had to pay for eishaku was called eishaku-ryo or joshaku-ryo.

sen.j: その額については、万寿2年(1025年)の『左経記』には700石を定法とすることがみられ、弘安10年(1287年)には諸国権守と同様に、最高額の1500疋と定められた。
sen.e: Concerning the amount, there is a description in "Sakeiki" (A Diary of MINAMOTO no Tsuneyori) that it was determined to be 126 cubic meters of rice crops, and it was decided in 1287 that the amount should be 1500 hiki (1 hiki: an amount of cloth from which two pieces of kimono could be generated), the maximum that was the same as that for gaining a Gon no kami (Provisional Governor) title.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Concerning the amount, there is a description in "Sakeiki" (A Diary of MINAMOTO no Tsuneyori) that stated the amount to be 126 cubic meters of rice crops. In 1287 the amount was stated to be 1500 hiki (1 hiki: an amount of cloth from which two pieces of kimono could be generated), the same maximum stated for the Gon no kami (Provisional Governor) title.

In 'Sakeiki' (a diary written by MINAMOTO no Tsuneyori in 1025) it states that this amount was 126 cubic meters of rice crop, while in 1287 the amount was stipulated to be at most 1500 hiki (a roll of cloth), the same as the amount stipulated for a Gon no Kami (Provisional Governer).
sen.cmt: FBに基づき修正しました。
